Exercise

Compute the determinants of \[ \mathrm{A}=\begin{bmatrix}{@a@}&{@a@}&{@c@}\\ {@a@}&{@b@}&{@a@}\\ {@a@}&{@b@}&{@c@}\\ \end{bmatrix} \ \text{ and } \ \mathrm{B}=\begin{bmatrix}{@a@}&0&0&{@c@}\\ {@c@}&0&0&{@a@}\\ {@a@}&0&{@c@}&0\\ 0&{@c@}&{@a@}&{@b@}\\ \end{bmatrix} . \] Laske matriisien \[ \mathrm{A}=\begin{bmatrix}{@a@}&{@a@}&{@c@}\\ {@a@}&{@b@}&{@a@}\\ {@a@}&{@b@}&{@c@}\\ \end{bmatrix} \ \text{ ja } \ \mathrm{B}=\begin{bmatrix}{@a@}&0&0&{@c@}\\ {@c@}&0&0&{@a@}\\ {@a@}&0&{@c@}&0\\ 0&{@c@}&{@a@}&{@b@}\\ \end{bmatrix} \] determinantit.

\(\operatorname{det}(\mathrm{A})=\) [[input:SAns1]] [[validation:SAns1]]

[[feedback:detA]]

\(\operatorname{det}(\mathrm{B})=\) [[input:SAns2]] [[validation:SAns2]]

[[feedback:detB]]

generalfeedback.text:
Determinants can be calculated for example by reducing the matrix to an upper triangle matrix or developing the determinant with respect to some row or column. Let's compute \(\det(\mathrm{A})\) by developing it with respect to the first row: \begin{eqnarray} \det(\mathrm{A})&=&{@a@}\left| \begin{matrix}{@b@} & {@a@} \\ {@b@} & {@c@} \\ \end{matrix}\right| -{@a@} \left| \begin{matrix}{@a@} & {@a@} \\ {@a@} & {@c@} \\ \end{matrix}\right| +({@c@}) \left| \begin{matrix}{@a@} & {@b@} \\ {@a@} & {@b@} \\ \end{matrix}\right| \nonumber \\ &=& {@a@}({@b@}\cdot ({@c@})-{@a@}\cdot {@b@})-{@a@}({@a@}\cdot ({@c@})-{@a@}^2)+({@c@})({@a@}\cdot {@b@}-{@a@}\cdot {@b@})\nonumber \\ &=& {@TAns1@}. \nonumber \end{eqnarray} The column of \(\mathrm{B}\) with the most zeros is the second column, so let's develop the determinant with respect to that: \[ \det(\mathrm{B}) = ({@c@})\left| \begin{matrix} {@a@}&0&{@c@}\\ {@c@}&0&{@a@}\\ {@a@}&{@c@}&0\\ \end{matrix}\right| . \] Here the \(3\times 3\)-determinant reduces to a \(2\times 2\)-determinant when developed with respect to the second column: \[ \det(\mathrm{B})=({@c@})\cdot (-({@c@}))\left| \begin{matrix} {@a@}&{@c@}\\ {@c@}&{@a@}\\ \end{matrix}\right| = -{@d@}^2({@a@}^2-({@c@})^2)={@TAns2@}. \]
Mallivastaus:
Determinantti voidaan laskea joko muuntamalla se yläkolmiomuotoon tai kehittämällä sopivan rivin tai sarakkeen mukaan. Lasketaan \(\det(\mathrm{A})\) kehittämällä 1. rivin mukaan: \begin{eqnarray} \det(\mathrm{A})&=&{@a@}\left| \begin{matrix}{@b@} & {@a@} \\ {@b@} & {@c@} \\ \end{matrix}\right| -{@a@} \left| \begin{matrix}{@a@} & {@a@} \\ {@a@} & {@c@} \\ \end{matrix}\right| +({@c@}) \left| \begin{matrix}{@a@} & {@b@} \\ {@a@} & {@b@} \\ \end{matrix}\right| \nonumber \\ &=& {@a@}({@b@}\cdot ({@c@})-{@a@}\cdot {@b@})-{@a@}({@a@}\cdot ({@c@})-{@a@}^2)+({@c@})({@a@}\cdot {@b@}-{@a@}\cdot {@b@})\nonumber \\ &=& {@TAns1@}. \nonumber \end{eqnarray} Matriisissa \(\mathrm{B}\) on paljon nollia, eniten niitä on 2. sarakkeessa, joten kehitetään determinantti sen mukaan: \[ \det(\mathrm{B}) = ({@c@})\left| \begin{matrix} {@a@}&0&{@c@}\\ {@c@}&0&{@a@}\\ {@a@}&{@c@}&0\\ \end{matrix}\right| . \] Tässä \(3\times 3\)-determinantti kannattaa kehittää 2. sarakkeen mukaan, jolloin saadaan \[ \det(\mathrm{B})=({@c@})\cdot (-({@c@}))\left| \begin{matrix} {@a@}&{@c@}\\ {@c@}&{@a@}\\ \end{matrix}\right| = -{@d@}^2({@a@}^2-({@c@})^2)={@TAns2@}. \]
